turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Ohh hello. Hi, how you doing? Uh, my name's Joe. I'm one of the doctors here at Babylon. Can I just confirm your name please?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yes. <UNSURE>Brian</UNSURE> <UNIN/>.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, sure. <UNSURE>My name's</UNSURE> Daniel <UNIN/>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Hi Daniel. And your date of birth? <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah. May <UNIN/>.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Nineteen ninety two.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Ninety two. OK, Daniel. And uh, are you in a, a comfortable and confidential place to talk?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah. Totally.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNIN/>, happy to go ahead. Great. How can I help?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, yeah, I just, my chest has been feeling really tight.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And how long has this been going on for Daniel?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, for about.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Three hours now.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And, so, tight chest, three hours. Um, and, so you're born in ninety two, so that makes you twenty six?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, and, you are, uh. Any shortness of breath at all, with that?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Twenty six, yeah.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, like a little bit, um. Yeah, a little bit short of breath, not too bad.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Uh, any cough? Wheeze?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, I'm feeling a bit wheezy, as well. <UNSURE>Kind of</UNSURE> cough <UNIN/>, coughing, yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Slight cough, yeah. <UNIN/>, sore throat? Runny nose? Sore ears?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <UNSURE>Yeah</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: You know I had a cold last week, and, it's not as bad as it was, but yeah, I had a sore throat, I had a runny nose. Uh, just feeling under the weather.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNSURE>Mm-hmm</UNSURE>. Are you feeling better now, other than the tight chest?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: I mean I feel worse, but the runny nose isn't as bad any more. <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Right. OK, OK, but you now, now you've got this, this um. So you've still got, still got uh, symptoms of a cold, essentially?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, but the cough's kind of stuck around.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Uh, ooh, yeah, OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And are you coughing up anything?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, no.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And, um, do you have any other medical problems, like asthma?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, yeah, I have asthma, I've had it for a while now, um.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: And then I have like, a hayfever, you know, and some allergies <UNSURE>just</UNSURE> to dust, <UNSURE>stuff like that</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>, OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: You have any, inhalers? Or any, any medications?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, yeah, so, uh, you know the um, uh, Ventolin. It's called uh, Salbutamol.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: I got that one, and then I have a steroid, a Clenil, Clenil inhaler.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNSURE>Clenil</UNSURE>, Clenil Modulite, yeah, OK.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <UNSURE>Yeah</UNSURE>, yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And um, uh, have you been using Clenil and the Ventolin? And how often have you been using them?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, well to be honest, I was away at uni last week, and I forgot to bring it with me, so I haven't really in the past week. <UNSURE>Uh</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Both <UNSURE>of them</UNSURE>?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Because <UNIN/>, because um, sorry, they ran out and I, I forgot to, go and grab the next one.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah, sure.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: About a week ago. Yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. All right, all right. So, so, so you've, you haven't got any Clenil, or any Ventolin at the moment?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Not with me right now, no, I ran out.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. All right. Um, and <UNIN/>, any drug allergies, that you know of?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No, no, not allergic to anything. Just like, just the, dust and stuff, but nothing, no drugs.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, great. Now, uh, do you, anyone in your family have any medical problems, that you know of?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, yeah, my mum has eczema, and my dad has asthma. <UNIN/>, ohh, when I was young, I also had eczema.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: And I had a milk protein allergy, when I was young too.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Hmm. OK. Um.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Right. So, just uh, <UNIN/>, do you have any other, sort of concerns? Or ideas about what might be going on? Or, um, hopes for this consultation?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Not really, like I feel like asthma's probably a part of it, and, probably getting my, inhalers would be helpful

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um. <UNSURE>It's just</UNSURE> kinda scary, 'cause I haven't had, a time like this where I've been so, tight, uh, in a long time.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah, absolutely, I can, I can imagine.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, well, it certainly sounds like uh, you've, you've had this cold, so you've got wheezy with a cough. Um, and it's non-productive cough, and you're short of breath. Uh, is the cough worse at night-time?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: I mean, it gets a little bit worse at night but, basically, just pretty consistent, and it hasn't gone away.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And you've got this tight, tight chest. But you, you wouldn't say you've got chest pains? It's more of a tight chest, is it?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No, not really pain, it's more like, tight.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: It just feels like sometimes, <UNIN/> I can't get a full breath in, you know.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah, sure. Um, OK. Well, I, I would quite like to, uh, certainly get you some, uh, Ventolin, Clenil Modulite. Have you had asthma exacerbations in the past?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Not in a long time. When I was young, a little bit, more like, back in high school. Um, but, I've been pretty good at taking my <UNIN/>, my inhalers, so, not, not so much any more.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Have you ever been to hospital, uh, as an inpatient? As in, you know, stayed in there overnight, for asthma?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, when I was in high school, I had to have a tube put down my throat.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Ohh, OK. So you, so, so you, uh, you <UNIN/>, you went to hospital, and had a, a, <UNIN/>. So you stayed in hospital for a few days did you, with an asthma exacerbation?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah I did, yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, but currently you're just on Ventolin and Clenil? And you haven't got any of those <UNSURE>steroids</UNSURE>, uh, those inhalers at the moment?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, I'm <UNSURE>doing</UNSURE> pretty good, I'm doing pretty good, just on the Clenil, and the Salbutamol.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. When, sorry, how old were you when you had that severe asthma exacerbation?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, I think I was like seventeen.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Sixteen maybe.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Sure. OK. Um.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Just to quantify how short of breath you are, um, I don't suppose you've got a peak flow with you? No, you won't have will you.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <UNSURE>No</UNSURE>, no.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNSURE>Um</UNSURE>, are you able to, uh, like walk up, flights of stairs OK? Walk on <UNSURE>the</UNSURE> flat OK, without getting to short of breath? Or um, are you short of breath at rest?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, I'm definitely not short of breath at rest, like, except for that feeling I was describing.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: It does when I'm walking up stairs, I do feel like, I have a little bit, more short of breath than I would normally be.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Sure. Yeah. OK, but you're not short of breath at rest at the moment?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No, no, no I'm not.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, fine. So, what, what I think, um, and just to, just to go over, <UNIN/>. Is there anything you had hoped about getting other than the uh, a, prescription for your inhalers? Was there anything else you'd hoped about getting from this?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Well I just wanna know that I'm OK, to just like keep. I just don't wanna have to get, um, that, that intubation again.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Sure, yeah, no, <UNSURE>absolutely</UNSURE>. Well, I'm really glad you have <UNIN/> talked to me today. I think what we can do is, is give you a prescription for, uh, some more of the inhalers. We can get that to you, within the hour, I would hope.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, and, uh, I think, what, the other thing I'd like to do is just give you a, dose of steroids. So this is, these are tablets which, um, you can take for five days. Uh, two tablets in the morning.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And, uh, that should just dampen down your asthmatic response, OK.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, now there are some side effects to the steroids. Which I should really tell you about, but please read the label, <UNSURE>that's</UNSURE> associated <UNSURE>with</UNSURE>. Don't be too worried about the side effects.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: They're <UNIN/>, most, you know <UNIN/>, most of the time the steroids are, very well tolerated. And, uh, you <UNIN/>. Have you had them in the past, do you know of?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Sorry, sorry, you were cutting in and out a little bit there. What were you saying?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>. Have you had steroids in the past?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um, I can't remember, probably. <UNSURE>I think so</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Probably, yeah I would <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> too. So, um, they, they can come, they can make you, your mood change, can be slightly low or <UNIN/> too, slightly high.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Can give you, a high blood sugar, um, and, uh, <UNSURE>their</UNSURE>. Uh, <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>, they can also cause rash, nausea, um, headaches, but, mostly is well-tolerated, and it should help your asthma an awful lot.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, uh, what I'd like to do is, is send you these, the, some prescriptions for your, uh, inhalers, <UNIN/>, ongoing. So you, um, you can, once you get better from this asthma attack, you can, you can, use the Clenil Modulite in the morning, with Ventolin as a PRN. <UNIN/>, so, a Ventolin when you need to, um, when you're getting <UNSURE>wheezy</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: If you should start to use the Ventolin more than, uh, every three hours.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Uh, at, at anytime, it's a good idea to seek medical attention. So, um, see a doctor, um, in some capacity.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <UNSURE>Yeah</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Uh, and, the other thing I'd like to send you is a spacer, which would allow the medication to actually, go into your lungs better. Have you, do you know what a spacer is? Have you used one before?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah, yeah, I, somebody told me how to use one a while ago. I don't, I don't really use it, to be honest, but.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Have you got one?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: I think I do, I have one somewhere.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. All right. Well, um, I'll send you another one, and it has some instructions about how to use it, but essentially, uh, couple of puffs to prime it, inside, breathing in and out, um, uh, for five or <UNIN/>, five or ten breaths.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Uh, yeah. So.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Uh, was there anything else that was on your mind? Or you're concerned about at this stage?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <UNIN/>, I think you got me covered.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK, and, and uh, I might give you some time off work as well. You can self-certify first seven days, but uh, I think I would advise you just to, rest a little bit until you're feeling a bit better, if you're OK with that. All right?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK, <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: All righty. Well, thank you very much.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNSURE>OK</UNSURE>. No worries. Any deterioration <UNSURE>in</UNSURE> your symptoms, like worsening shortness of breath. Um, or just generally concerning symptoms, uh, pain in your chest tightness, uh, feeling light-headed.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Uh, then, seek further medical attention anytime please. OK?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: All right, sounds good.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Thank you.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <UNSURE>OK</UNSURE>, thank you. Bye bye.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Bye bye.
